posts.sub: Is chkdsk supposed to take this long?
posts.com: I recently got the blue screen of death and a notification that I need to restart my PC to repair a drive. I used chkdsk /r, but it's been 30 minutes and is barely making any progress on stage 4. It only makes progress if I press a key while the command prompt is open. Is this normal? I've attached a screenshot of what it says in the command prompt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1297776
OP here, i forgot to ask: Is there any way I can safely stop chkdsk and shut down my pc? From what I've read online it's not advised as it could brick my drive. Would it be possible to safely restart or do something? No progress is being made on stage 4 and the amount of time it would take is concerning.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Depends on how large your disk is, and how fucked it is. Yes, it can take hours. It's not really the kind of thing you start on a lark.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1297790
My disk is 1 tb with around 250 gb of free space. I can accept that it could take hours, but why isn't it making any progress? It's been stuck for the past 20+ minutes, but only makes progress if I press a key while the command prompt is open. I'm just so confused.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Did you click inside the window? If it says "Select" in the title bar, then it's paused while waiting for you to select something in the window. Press a key and stop clicking on things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1297800
Yes. I clicked inside the window and it said "Select" in the title bar. I pressed a key and now it's making progress. The ETA is also decreasing. I probably made you facepalm with my tech illiteracy but thanks for helping me, much appreciated <3

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1297776
>Is chkdsk supposed to take this long?
It can take hours with the TB size CMR type drives. The great mistake is when you do SMR drivers which are far far slower.

SMR -- shingle magnetic recording
CMR -- conventional magnetic recording

The Seagate 8TB external drives sold at Costco are SMR which will take 1.5 days to do an actual format where zeroes are actually written and checked sector by sector.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1297829
>The great mistake is when you do SMR drivers which are far far slower.
This is a lie, SMR reads at the same speed as a CMR disk of the same density, and faster than an CMR disk of the same capacity.
>it's not a lie
Then explain how it would be slower, when read operations are exactly the same

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1297829
>o an actual format where zeroes are actually written and checked sector by sector.
a) that's not what OP's talking about
b) that's a pathological workload, write the whole disk then read the whole disk

posts.sub: Is there a way to make faster I/O operations in late linux distros?
posts.com:
Hello there anon!!!!!
The shit is in the latest distros I have been using it takes lots of times to move files using ethernets or removable mediums.
Besides the innate limitations of these methods, I have noted that in fedora 35-37, latest opensuse release and thumbleweeds, and rocky linux the speeds are unusually slower than, say, puppy or rescuecd. example:
in these live/prior distros I usually got around 3x MB/s in microsd devices and now it roams the 19-25 (average max). Then whats fucked?
I suspect it has to be with making synchronus I/O, but then how can turn it asynchronus?
Or what else must be tuned or added to speed the transfers a bit?
I'm ruling out the device type, since I'm using mechanicals HD, NVMe 3/4, usb 3.x, micro sd U20... (in ext4/exfat) and all gives me more or less the same output rates. So I'm guessing this is a systemic issue.
Prior to the updates it doesn't matter what fs or medium was used it was consistent over 80MB/s or more.
Thanks anon and Merry Christmas and Happy New Year, be safe anonbro!!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1297834
It's just write caching, pull the card out immediately after your "consistent over 80MB/s or more" and your data will all be fucked because it's not on the card yet.

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

posts.sub: Animated movie about a kid losing his sister in a city
posts.com:
I need help finding an animated movie about a kid losing his sister in a big city. I can give you all the details I can remember.

Plot: A little boy and his sister somehow get lost in a big, trashy city. At some point in the movie, the little boy loses his sister in a huge group of people during what looks like rush hour. The sister is swept away in a big, dramatic scene as they both frantically try to find each other.

The people clear and the boy realizes that his sister is nowhere to be scene. The boy then goes on a journey through the city to find his sister and meets a bunch of weird throwaway characters along the way. I remember one of the characters being a rude hotdog vendor smoking a comically large cigar and ashing in the hotdog water.

Eventually, the kid meets a man in a subway station at night. The boy was startled by how gruff and intimidating the man looked, but was calmed when the man turned away from him and laid down in a pile of newspapers. I remember a sappy, sad orchestral song began to play as the kid realized that the man was homeless.

The two of them talked, had a heart-to-heart, yadda yadda yadda, then the kid revealed that he lost his sister in the city and had been looking for her all day. The homeless man then decides to join the boy on his journey to find his sister.

The two leave the subway and a montage of them meeting more strange, rude and "wacky" characters plays. The montage ends with two of them ending up at the entrance of a dark, "spooky" alleyway. The boy is too scared to go inside the alley, but the homeless man tells the boy something like he's been in lots of alleys like this one, so he's got nothing to worry about.

The two of them walk into the alley. The kid looks really nervous as he hesitantly walks behind the homeless man. A scuttling sound echoing through the alley and makes the kid turn around. When he looks back, the homeless man in gone.

>cont

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A voice says something like "up here, child" and the kid looks up to see a giant spider wearing a black suit, a top hat, and what I remember as four monocles on half of his eyes. The spider asks why the kid is scared, then the kid answers that he lost his friend in the alley.

The spider slowly crawls down from the alley wall and says something like "if he was a friend, why would he leave you hear all alone?" I should also note that the spider had a posh English accent and a deep voice.

The spider starts to sing in a kind of slow, opera-esque voice. These are the lyrics I remember, but not sure how accurate they are after so many years.

"Don't you want a friend? A special kind of friend? I will be there 'till the end. I'm just that kind of friend. I may look a bit scary, perhaps a tad too hairy, but a gentleman's cane I carry. But I understand why you're wary."

The giant spider then weaves a piano from his webs and starts playing an upbeat, jazzy sounding song about how he can be the boy's new friend and how lots of people in the city wouldn't make good friends for the boy.

The musical number was full of visual gags, the one I remember the most was the spider playing the drums, the piano and a saxophone or trumpet all at once. The song starts to pick up in speed, the kid is playfully picked up by the spider and set on his back, and they both start dancing.

The song gets faster and I think the lyrics get more revealing about the spider's intentions, then the spider crawls up the alley wall with the kid still on his back. The music crescendos on a shot of the kid's shocked face and then cuts to a shot of the homeless man stuck in a giant web with webbing covering his mouth.

That's right about the time my little brother would start whining about how the movie was scaring him and that he wanted to turn it off. We had a VCR in the living room, so if you watched something, the whole family did, and I only got to watch maybe 30 minutes of it twice.

>cont

posts.name: Anonymous

I know it's been a long-ass post, but I really want to find this movie again so I can finish it with my little brother after all these fucking years. If any of you remember this movie, please fucking tell me what it is. Been looking everywhere by searching "spider wearing suit movie," "kids get lost in city movie," and shit like "giant spider musical movie."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The proper way is just however you like it. Vanilla is fine, unless you:
want to filter out certain content
often try to source images
often try to look through archives
want to customize UI (use 4chanX and OneeChan for this, although the presets are pretty jarring and I made a ton of settings changes to get it closer to vanilla)
want features like thread watcher, prefetch, show images only, keybinds, custom boards list (including links to generals), etc

I do recommend getting 4chan external sounds since it allows you to add and listen to sound files on boards other than /wsg/ /wsr/ and /gif/, and it doesn't break >>>/global/rules/17 since it's just a link to another site in the filename. How often you'll see it used varies quite a bit between boards.
If you go on flagboards, there are some extensions in >>>/int/extraflag including adding voluntary regional flags and flag listers.
There was recently a thread about 4chan extensions here that had a few other things listed: https://archived.moe/wsr/thread/1292547

There can only be 150 threads on a board. When you post in a thread you bump it, making it go to the top. When a new thread gets made, the one at the bottom, which is the one to be bumpped the longest time ago, gets archived or deleted, depending on the board. Archived threads last around 7 or more days but this may vary by board or by the speed of the board, not too sure about this. You can't see all archived posts in the archive section, only recent ones.
You can only bump your own thread once with the same IP. You can post without bumping by typing "sage" in the options field. Moderators can "autosage" threads, making them unable to be bumpped, making them get bumpped off the board faster.
There are plenty of external archives but they don't last forever. You can see the ones still alive here >>1296569 along with the boards they archive.
What brings you here?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
the short answer is to always be mentally and socially active

mentally activity:
>Mentally challenging activities, such as learning a new skill, adopting a new hobby or engaging in formal education, may have short and long-term benefits for your brain. To keep your mind active, it is important to participate in activities that expose your mind to new topics.
>Challenge yourself to games with strategy or high-level reading material, or determine how to approach a familiar task in a more effective way. Selecting activities you enjoy will increase the likelihood that you will continue to engage in them over time.
also formal education, if you are a senior, you may be able to take university classes for free

socially activity:
>Social engagement is associated with reduced rates of disability and mortality, and may also reduce risk for depression. Remaining socially active may support brain health and possibly delay the onset of dementia. There are many ways to stay socially active in your community, and these activities will provide the greatest connection to others.
>Participation in clubs, volunteer efforts and other community pursuits may be valuable in maintaining your overall health. Many of these social activities are low-cost or free, such as joining a walking group or book club in your neighborhood. Staying socially active can also be as simple as engaging with friends and family on a regular basis.

these are recommedations from an alzheimer's support group btw, but it's still good health advice for everyone
i would add that if you have a spare 15 min each day, do a light walk around the block, cardio helps your head too

I live in america, and this year, I will have to file a 1099-K tax form because I made roughly $2,000 dollars this year from selling old, personal items on ebay. Some people have told me that when I file the 1099-K tax form, I'll probably end up having to pay $250-ish dollars. However, others have said that because I was only selling personal items, and because I did not make an actual profit, that odds are I will pay next to nothing.
The items I sold throughout the year went something like this:
A GameCube I bought for 100 USD in 2005-ish that has been collecting dust since 2007 (since the Wii can play all GC titles), I sold this year for 80 USD. So on and so forth.
Do you agree with the people who think because I wasn't making a profit with these sales, that come tax time I'm most likely going to see a paltry sum to pay when the time comes? Or am I misunderstanding.
Thanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1297602
Selling stuff you already own at a profit is income. Selling stuff you already own at a loss is not.

Sales tax is the buyer's problem and eBay collects it automatically anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1297602
>If your sales are akin to having a garage sale — i.e., you unload belongings for less than what you originally paid — there typically is no reason to report what you pulled in, said Weston at the American Institute of CPAs. Essentially, there is no "income" to report.
https://www.cnbc.com/amp/2021/03/26/its-going-to-get-harder-to-avoid-telling-the-irs-about-income-from-online-sales.html

Obviously this is not legal advice under the legal meaning of "legal advice".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1297612
>Am I correct in thinking that someone like me would file the 1099-K form alongside the 1040 form?
My understanding is yes, but I'm not a US taxpayer.
From what I can gather:
- if any transaction made a profit you have to count that as income, even if all the others made a loss
- you just report the money you received on the 1099-k
- on the regular tax return, you declare how much total income you made from selling items that actually made a profit

No, that's something different.

OP asked an "elided question", a question where the actual question clause is elided, to be assumed from context. That's not the same thing as "uptalk", which is a statement that doesn't ask any question, but is spoken as if it did. Key word here is "spoken".

Examples of elided questions:
>Reinstalling the drivers doesn't fix it?
>Reinstalling the drivers doesn't fix it[, so what should I try next]?

>requesting newer fps games recommendations without woke garbage?
>requesting newer fps games recommendations without woke garbage[; which games meet these criteria]?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>1297281
I think >>1297313 is right. It just has some weird font settings applied to it.
I have that font on my system and I was able to reproduce it (pic related).

Top line is from your pic. The bottom 2 lines are in my terminal using DejaVuSansMono.
The middle line looks almost identical, except when I zoom in your pic seems like it has some minor anti-aliasing. But maybe that's just because the pic was re-sized?

Anyway, the settings I used for the 2nd line are: antialias=false, hintstyle=hintslight, pixelsize=16
For the 3rd line it's the same but I turned on antialiasing.

But if the only reason you like it is because it has that "thin" crisp look, then instead of messing with font settings maybe you should just get a font with embedded bitmaps. If it has bitmaps then it always looks thin and crispy (assuming your system enables bitmap fonts).
Fonts like Terminus, InputMono, or even MSGothic.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294232
What do you mean by "seedy"?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1294247
Sordid and disreputable.

Examples as applied to the 3 named series:
Watari-kun - starts with MC being hounded by a selfish and aggressive girl, who wants to non-sexually pair with him because he was the only stability in her personal life. MC instead asks out another girl who is known to be the paragon of virtue; this is immediately revealed to be false, as she is secretly sexually aggressive due to having low self-esteem.

Gleipnir - starts with female blackmailing the MC into doing her bidding. Devolves into a soft love triangle when it's revealed that she is hunting her sister, who is the previous girlfriend of MC.

Suzuka - two hard-working athletes attempt a relationship, despite being a terrible fit for each other. MC is extremely low IQ and terrible at communication. Female slowly revealed to have a significantly bad personality and impossibly high standards. Disreputable actions, poor judgement, and push them into a long-term relationship that has severe negative externalities (and 1 very positive externality) on their friends, family, and related social institutions.

FWIW I don't think she was actually horny. Rather, she was trading access to her body for loyalty. She knew that her body was a highly-valued commodity. In her immature worldview, she could lock down this "King of Nice Guys" with this strategy.

The dramatic irony here is that this would work with any other suitor ("All the other boys are after me for my body") but it was the exact opposite of what appealed to Watari because of his extreme familiarity with the risks associated with teenage sex.
